keywords: Y-chromosome, sDY gene, PCR amplification, genomic DNA isolation, Chelex resin.

abstract:
A team of researchers, led by Yano et al., discovered a gene on the Y-chromosome called sDY that determines male sex in O. mykiss (rainbow trout). To identify genetic males, a lab technique called Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is used. The PCR method amplifies the presence of this gene in genomic DNA extracted from either red blood cells or fin tissue.

The necessity of this method lies in being able to identify and distinguish between male and female trout for various scientific research purposes, such as studying sex-specific behaviors or analyzing the effects of hormones on their development.

Initially, Yano et al. provided the primers for PCR amplification but the scientists modified the process by using Chelex resin from BioRad to isolate genomic DNA. This modification was made to reduce costs in the assay. The presence of sDY gene is confirmed through PCR results, thereby identifying genetic males with ease and efficiency.

Overall, this method allows for quick and cost-effective identification of male trout using their genomic DNA. It solves the issue of laboriously sexing fish visually by observing physical characteristics. This not only saves time but also minimizes potential stress and harm to the fish during manual inspection.

description:
The text body discusses the identification of the male sex determining gene, sDY, on the Y-chromosome in O. mykiss using PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction). This discovery was reported by Yano et al., 2012a. For genetic male identification, it is necessary to verify the presence of this gene in genomic DNA obtained from red blood cells or fin tissue samples.

The method for PCR amplification of sDY employs primers reported by Yano et al., 2012a,b. The original procedure was modified for cost reduction with the use of Chelex resin (BioRad, Richland, CA) for genomic DNA isolation instead of traditional methods.

The PCR reaction mixture typically contains: template DNA, deoxyribonucleotide triphosphates (dNTPs), primers, MgCl2, and Taq polymerase in appropriate buffer. The temperature cycling program usually includes an initial denaturation step at 95°C, followed by multiple cycles of denaturation, annealing, and extension steps at specific temperatures.

The genomic DNA is isolated using Chelex resin suspension, which is added to the sample in a tube and heated to 95°C for 10 minutes to release the bound DNA from proteins. After centrifugation, the supernatant containing the purified genomic DNA can be used as a template for PCR amplification.

The specific primers for sDY amplification are not mentioned in the text body, but they were reported by Yano et al., 2012a,b, and are critical for initiating the synthesis of complementary strands during the PCR reaction. The cycling conditions, such as denaturation temperature (Td), annealing temperature (Ta), extension temperature (Te), and cycle number, may vary depending on the specific primers and the sequence of interest.

In summary, the text body describes a method for identifying genetic males in O. mykiss using PCR amplification of the sex-determining gene sDY, with modifications to reduce costs by using Chelex resin (BioRad) for DNA isolation. The PCR reaction includes template DNA, primers, dNTPs, MgCl2, Taq polymerase, and buffer, and the temperature cycling program consists of denaturation, annealing, and extension steps.
